channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fillon Scandal Indicts, Foremost, France’s Political Elite
item.media:description: The presidential candidate François Fillon in Paris on Tuesday. Mr. Fillon’s nepotism scandal has added another major element of uncertainty to an already unsettled political time.
item.description: The presidential candidate François Fillon is in deep trouble over payments to his wife and children. But there is a long history of such cozy arrangements.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Norwegian Ex-Premier Is Stopped at Dulles Airport Over Iran Visit
item.media:description: Kjell Magne Bondevik, right, a former Norwegian prime minister, speaking in Tehran in 2008 with Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Iran’s president at the time.
item.description: The former leader, Kjell Magne Bondevik, was questioned for an hour. “I explained to the officer who I was and that I had been to Iran for a conference on extremism,” he said.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: E.U. Vows to Slow Migration on Sea Route That Claimed Thousands of Lives
item.media:description: Migrants rescued from a rubber boat last month in the Mediterranean Sea, north of Libya. A record 4,579 people died last year along the so-called Central Mediterranean route — typically while trying to reach Italy from Libya.
item.description: A record 4,579 people died along the so-called Central Mediterranean route last year, and the bloc’s leaders said they aimed to “break the business model of smugglers.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: For Quadruple Amputee, Year of Illness ‘Was the Most Brilliant’
item.media:description: Alex Lewis, whose life was changed by an infection that cost him his arms and legs, at his home near Stockbridge, England.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Alex Lewis, a British pub owner, lost his arms and legs to a blood infection. He now says the devastating ordeal made him the man he is — “in a good way.”
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: No Extra Forces Needed in Gulf Now, Defense Chief Says
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis on Friday in Tokyo. “We stand firmly, 100 percent, shoulder to shoulder with you and the Japanese people,” he told Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.
item.description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said the United States would not beef up its military presence in the Persian Gulf, despite concerns over Iran.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and MOTOKO RICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Iran Treads Cautiously With Trump. So Far.
item.media:description: Iranian Hard-liners have been critical of President Hassan Rouhani. With President Trump in power, some dismiss him as a figure of the past, the right answer in the Obama era but the wrong one now.
item.description: Even hard-liners in the Iranian government are showing restraint, concerned that the smallest provocation could lead to military conflict.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: What You Need to Know About Trump’s Statement on Israeli Settlements
item.media:description: The security fence of the West Bank Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, near Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: The reception and implications of the White House’s call to curb Israeli construction of new settler homes in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on Iran Over Missile Test
item.media:description: Members of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps during a military parade in 2014. The corps is one of 25 individuals and entities the United States has designated for sanctions.
item.description: The administration announced penalties on 25 individuals and entities, including those associated with the Revolutionary Guards Corps.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Unease in Colombia, as Old Enemies Become New Neighbors
item.media:description: Tierra Grata, a settlement in La Paz, Colombia, where former rebels have moved. This year, 7,000 across the country are to surrender their guns.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: Among the 7,000 FARC rebels surrendering their guns this year, those who have moved near La Paz, find townspeople with long memories are watching warily.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Trump Travel Ban Disrupts Work and Meetings at the United Nations
item.description: The impact of President Trump’s executive order is reverberating through the United Nations system.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sinosphere: Pollution Leads to Greater Risk of Dementia Among Older Women, Study Says
item.description: The study, led by researchers at the University of Southern California, looked at places with high concentrations of fine particulate matter — the kind common in air pollution across China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Punjab’s Heroin Problem Bursts Into the Open as an Election Issue
item.media:description: A rehabilitation center in Raikot, part of the state of Punjab in India. Punjab’s heroin problem is escalating, an issue in state elections on Saturday.
item.description: Once hushed up, drug use in an Indian state is fueling anti-incumbent sentiment and the rising electoral fortunes of a new party.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Videos U.S. Seized in Yemen Raid Appear to Show Nothing New
item.description: The military trumpeted the videos as an important find, but later admitted that they appeared to be 10 years old, similar to Qaeda training messages from 2007.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Canada Today: Tragedy at a Mosque, and Welcoming a New Colleague
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau spoke Thursday in Montreal at a funeral ceremony for three of the victims of the shooting at the Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec.
item.description: A look at the news of the week, including a remembrance of victims in Quebec City, and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s handling of the new U.S. administration.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec City

item.title: Justin Trudeau, Facing Pressure to Oppose Donald Trump, Opts to Get Along
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Parliament last month. He appears to be putting solid trade relations with the United States ahead of criticism of President Trump.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Many leaders of countries allied with the United States face the same situation, but none has anywhere near as much to lose as Canada does.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Rohingya Face ‘Campaign of Terror’ in Myanmar, U.N. Finds
item.media:description: A refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, near the Burmese border. Over 200 Rohingya villagers who fled Myanmar to Bangladesh gave harrowing testimony to United Nations investigators about the treatment they received.
item.description: Hundreds have been killed and gang-raped and 90,000 forced from their homes, according to a report released by the United Nations high commissioner for human rights.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump’s Granddaughter, 5, Sings in Chinese, and China Swoons
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump, with her daughter, Arabella, arrived at the Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 21.
item.description: A video of Ivanka Trump’s daughter, Arabella, singing a New Year’s song in Chinese has gone viral on social media in China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Kellyanne Conway Admits ‘Bowling Green Massacre’ Error
item.media:description: Kellyanne Conway, left, counselor to President Trump, with Hope Hicks, director of strategic communications, and Stephen Miller, senior adviser for policy at the White House in January.
item.description: Ms. Conway, a counselor to President Trump, cited a terrorist attack in Kentucky that never happened. She said it was a mistake.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: Travel Ban Drives Wedge Between Iraqi Soldiers and Americans
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers in Mosul. “This decision by Trump blows up our liberation efforts of cooperation and coordination with American forces,” one officer said.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump’s order banning Iraqis from entering the United States came in the midst of the Iraqi Army’s fight for the city of Mosul.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO

item.title: Jim Mattis Says U.S. Is ‘Shoulder to Shoulder’ With Japan
item.media:description: The American defense secretary, Jim Mattis, left; Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, second right; and the Japanese defense minister, Tomomi Inada, right, in Tokyo on Friday.
item.description: The new defense secretary, visiting Tokyo, sought to dispel any doubt about the American commitment to the countries’ mutual security treaty.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Oil Spill Near Chennai, India, Threatens Wildlife
item.media:description: Collecting water samples near Chennai, India, on Monday, days after two oil tankers collided off the coast.
item.description: Port officials noticed oil in the Bay of Bengal on Saturday night but thought it was a minor leak from a tanker collision. Days later, miles of coastline were affected.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Assailant Near Louvre Is Shot by French Soldier
item.media:description: Officers secured the area around the Louvre on Friday.
item.description: A man with two large knives was seriously wounded after he lunged at military personnel near the Paris institution, shouting “God is great” in Arabic.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Office of South Korea’s Embattled Leader Blocks Search of Presidential Compound
item.media:description: The Blue House, the presidential compound in Seoul, South Korea. President Park Geun-hye has been holed up there since the National Assembly voted to impeach her in December on charges of corruption and abuse of power.
item.description: Prosecutors investigating President Park Geun-hye’s corruption scandal had a warrant but were told they needed presidential consent to search the offices.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: North Korean Leader’s Top Enforcer Is Now the One Getting Purged
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, at an undisclosed location in January. The decision by Mr. Kim to purge his top enforcer highlights the turmoil that has engulfed the upper reaches of his regime.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The dismissal of the head of the secret police underlines the turmoil that has engulfed the upper reaches of Kim Jong-un’s regime.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bangladesh’s Creeping Islamism
item.description: Religious conservatives have managed to paint secularism as anti-Islamic. The new textbooks prove it.
item.dc:creator: K. ANIS AHMED

item.title: Editorial: Testing Europe’s Values
item.media:description: Refugees being thrown life jackets during a rescue operation off the coast of Libya last November.
item.description: Refugees must be allowed legal channels to reach Europe from Libya, where they face intolerable conditions.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Malaysian Trilogy
item.media:description: A protester’s scarf bearing the logo of the Bersih, an electoral-reform movement, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in November.
item.description: Patronage, communal politics, an electoral one-party state. That’s how the prime minister stays in power despite epic scandals and waning popularity.
item.dc:creator: CHIN-HUAT WONG
